\"Machine Learning: Field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.\", 1959

\"Machine Learning: A computer program is said to learn from experience E, with respect to some task T, and some performance measure P, if its performance on T as measured by P improves with experience E. \", 1997
Supervised Learning. The algorithm is given training data which contains the "correct answer" for each example.
Unsupervised Learning. The algorithm looks for structure in the training data, like finding which examples are similar to each other, and group them in clusters.
The task T of that system is to flag credit card transactions as fraudulent or not. The performance measure P could be the percentage of fraudulent transactions that are detected.

The system learns if the percentage of fraudulent transactions that are detected increases over time. Here the experience E is the set of already processed transaction records. Once a transaction is processed, then we know if it is a fraud or not, and we can feed that information to the system for it learn.
